There seems to be failure to undestand that the old testament is not one homogeneous work, but a collection of the oral tradition of the Jewish people from the beginning of their culture on. Some of it is myth to establish fundamental truth, some is history combined with spiritual commentary, some is prophecy, some is worship songs. If everything in the old testament is literally true then can somebody point me to the exact location of the valley of the shadow of death referenced in Psalm 22? As a general rule the closer to the present day the more historical and less mythical the books become, hence the validity of trusting the prophets. In any case, it the precise circumstances of the prophcies aren't all that relevant, the fact that they were made (they we recorded, so someone must have made them) and fulfilled by Jesus is enough.

 It sounds like you are saying that you think these stories have absolutely no value/relevancy beyond a literal presentation of an event.
 If that were the case, what would be the purpose of them being included in the bible? There are millions of other historical events that could have been included if all it was was an historical account. But they weren't.
 This, IMHO, is one of the problems with interpreting these stories literally. One tends to not look beyond the literal meaning. This is sad, as there is so much more going on than just what is happening on the surface.

 actually, the sections of the bible are implicitly denoted as to what to expect where. "psalms" are literally songs and poetry, "proverbs" are sayings of wisdom. "genesis" means the beginning. "exodus" is the journey of the israelites. the books of the prophets are books of prophesy and the life of the prophets. "samuel", "kings" and "chronicles" are books about the succession of judges and kings that ruled israel in those times. its pretty clear-cut
